Wisdom, hence!  and seek thy crony,</br>Religion grave,</br>In some lone cave,</br>With Hermit-Virtue, lanthorn-jaw'd, and bony!</br>Or seek some parsonage mean,</br>Where yews, and ghastly graves deform the scene;</br>Where the tythe-pigs seldom squeak,</br>But squalling brats molest the Vicar meek!</br>Nor let him read, nor let him pray,</br>Nor e'er know Pleasure's holiday;</br>There, Wisdom, there, with sober Sadness stay!</br>Hither, Goddess blythe and boon,</br>Whom on earth we title FUN;</br>But the name in Heaven you bear,</br>Can I tell, who am not there?</br>Spread thy wing, and hither flee,</br>Since I solely worship thee!</br>Whom (as sing the seers of yore)</br>Malice keen to laughter bore,</br>Goddess from thy jovial air,</br>We thy jocund fire declare;</br>Goddess, in thy spirit keen,</br>All thy mother's force is seen.

Haste then, Goddess, and to me</br>Bring thy whole artillery:</br>Squibs and crackers, salt and brandy,</br>Sheets for ghosts, and bludgeons handy.</br>Batter down the Shrovetide cocks;</br>Batter down the borough's blocks,</br>Where, beside the travel'd way,</br>Wont plebeian wights display</br>Or Pomona's fruitage fair,</br>Or the potter's shining ware.—</br>Mark!  I hear, the thund'rous fall</br>Bolts out Goodman from his stall,</br>Up the street, and up the lane,</br>Some to scold, but more to cane.

Bring turnips scoop'd, and bladders blown;</br>Bring the sling, and bring the stone,</br>This for window, that for door;</br>Instruments a thousand more,</br>Thou shalt bring for urchin-play,</br>On the truant holyday!

O what bliss, at dead of night</br>Village Thestylis to fright,</br>From the market as she steals</br>Homeward by the church, and feels</br>All the fears her childhood brought</br>From the tales her Grandam taught.</br>Wintry night, and wintry wind,</br>Dart their horrors o'er her mind.</br>Candle plac'd on bladder blown,</br>Glares a skull upon the stone.</br>Phrensied at the ghastly sight,</br>Screams the nymph, and faints with fright.</br>Scours away the raptur'd boy.—</br>Fun, O Fun, how vast thy joy!

Flooding fount of my delight!</br>Fount of my supremest might!</br>When thy tide supplies my course,</br>Countless wrecks proclaim its force.</br>Thy puissance to restrain,</br>Wisdom lifts an aegis vain.</br>Virtue's self, beneath thy ray,</br>Throws her robe of state away.</br>Wit, that puny ape of thee,</br>Dares not wear thy armoury:</br>Feeble flies his silver dart;</br>Thine of steel divides the heart.
What would hypercritics do,</br>Were the beasts not quell'd by you?</br>Stripp'd of your offensive geer,</br>Tiny bodies they appear;</br>Nor to battle dare advance,</br>Till you arm their ignorance.
Bear me hence, from rustic sport,</br>To my Queen's majestic court,</br>Where in tower'd Augusta she</br>Shines with crown'd authority.

There, 'mid pomp of tragic rage,</br>Oft will I frequent the stage,</br>And will urge the damning groan,</br>When some novel buskin's on;</br>Or the shrill-ton'd cat-call use,</br>Fatal to the strutting Muse.

Sometimes at the dead of night</br>Let me rise, with zeal to write</br>Tales tremendous, murders dire,</br>Here a plague, and there a fire;</br>Or by fictions of my pen,</br>Discord pour on peaceful men;</br>And in covert veil'd from view,</br>Pierce the grave ones thro' and thro'.

Virtue, genius, erudition,</br>Make unequal men's condition,</br>But that you your level lay,</br>To reduce their swelling sway,</br>Or by laughable confusion,</br>Check at times their proud intrusion.</br>Thus the comic wag with ease</br>Tumbles down sage Socrates;</br>And with bellows arm'd, and pokers,</br>Rochester, the cream of jokers,</br>With the fun of Buckingham</br>Hyde's puissant torrent dam.

When to imps of yonger sort</br>I resign robuster sport,</br>All the tricks in taverns known,</br>Tricks that once were all my own.</br>Let me then repair my race</br>In some water-drinking place.</br>Virtue says — but then we know,</br>Virtue ever was thy foe—</br>Wisdom says — that pedant prig,</br>Or by some yclept a gig—</br>That where case should most abound,</br>Fun the worst disease is found.

Bear me then to Bladad's town,</br>Where you reign with most renown;</br>And, though Anstey should be there,</br>Arm'd by you, I need not fear,</br>Fear his humour's Attic kind,</br>Fear his wit with truth combin'd;</br>Virtue, learning, wit, and taste,</br>Banish'd thence with Anstey haste,</br>Fun, my Empress, bids you flee,</br>Folly, Bath, and her, and me.

Now, dear Goddess, what remains,</br>Meed of all my loyal pains?</br>Thro' thy warfare I am sure,</br>Thou thy champion wilt secure</br>From resentment's fatal blow,</br>Want, and pain's extremest woe?</br>That I may in hope behold</br>Life in gather'd honours old,</br>Wanting strength, yet blest with ease,</br>And departing by degrees.</br>Wilt thou then the pillow lend</br>Of the lov'd consoling friend?</br>Conscious then of actions kind,</br>Shall I soothe my mourning mind?</br>See, with Loveday, roses blow</br>'Mid my honour'd age's snow,</br>And arriv'd at life's last bench,</br>Heaven in hope with Loveday reach?</br>Shall I shew indeed, when age</br>Pours on me his wintry rage,</br>All within secure and calm,</br>Friendship's warmth, and virtue's balm?</br>From without, while well-earn'd praise</br>Decks my dome with sun-bright rays,</br>Shall I, Loveday-like, perceive</br>Finer forms in life's cool eve,</br>Than in manhood's busy noon,</br>Met its warm meridian fun?</br>Heaven in prospect, and a tomb</br>Deck'd with wreaths that ever bloom?</br>Tears of tender mem'ry, shed,</br>Not to weep, but praise the dead;</br>And a lasting meed to grace</br>Conquest in the noblest race?

Fun!  I do but jest with thee</br>Thou shalt never govern me!</br>Taught by Truth, and forc'd to think</br>Thee more dev'lish than divine,</br>Cheating still thy souls with chink;—</br>While Wisdom pays with weighty coin!</br>
